content:
I know you think you have a simple issue and someone should be able to wave a wand over it and it will just fix itself.

Unfortunately we are seeing more and more of this, especially with people with the multi gigabyte mail accounts adding their account to a new device and exceeding their mail providers daily download limit, leaving them waiting. For example, Google offer Download with IMAP of 2500 MB per day, so a mail account approaching the 15Gb free limit will take the best part of a week to download.

Then we have issues with security software that can not cope with the large continuous mail downloads that setting up a large mail account can represent. They just drops their bundle so mail just basically stops until the system is rebooted. Nothing to do with Thunderbird, but that is where the complete failure of fetching mail is actually seen.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Here is the recovery for a forgotten primary password: Choose Tools -> Developer Tools > Error Console, paste the expression: 

  openDialog("chrome://pippki/content/resetpassword.xhtml")     and press the Evaluate button. That will open a dialog asking you if you want to reset your password. If Evaluate is not seen, press enter key. When prompted, press the Reset button.

This removes all account passwords so they will need to be entered again.

content:
Anti-virus software often causes the symptoms you describe. These are some generic suggestions to avoid problems with anti-virus software.

Create an exception in your anti-virus software for the Thunderbird profile folder, so that the anti-virus real-time scanner will not scan it. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_how-to-find-your-profile

Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Keep it working. https://kb.mozillazine.org/Keep_it_working_-_Thunderbird

And last but not least, backup your Thunderbird profile on a regular basis. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/profiles-where-thunderbird-stores-user-data#w_backing-up-a-profile

content:
The version of TB y run is 128.1.0esr (32 bits)

Is there some reason you are using the 32bit version?

The forum reports you as using a 64bit version of Windows and as such, the bug I assume is being referred to by Corey only applies to 32bit versions of Thunderbird anyway. It is time to use the 64bit version on 64bit operating systems unless you use line of business tools that use 32bit MAPI to send mail. (that is another bug) 

User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/127.0.0.0 Safari/537.36

Bug https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1911076

There is also this report. https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1912314 But I am not even sure that is not just a misdirected support request.

It's difficult to give a progress report or ETA yet, aside from re-confirming that we're committed to an iOS version of Thunderbird. We need to get a solid and polished Thunderbird for Android published first. In the meantime, we're currently hiring for a mobile manager, after which we'll start recruiting iOS developers. As things stand, I wouldn't expect to see any code until next year. But hopefully that flies by. We totally understand the demand for an iOS version!

content: One is an error retrieving mail. Often the issue is a huge library of mail on the server and POP mail set to leave all messages on the server. The other is an error typing to setup a new mail account in Thunderbird. Which is it? You certainly are unlikely to fix issues involving STAT (which is a mail transfer command meaning status request to the mail server) by adding the account over again.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: try disabling your antivirus product and see if that allows mail. It is often an issue post update. These antivirus products are fairly temperamental.

content: The simplest way is to highlight the content of the email, press cntl and 'c' (or edit>copy) to copy and open a word processor and press cntl and 'v' (or edit>paste) to paste into the word processor. repeat for each message. OR, you could just do file>print and click 'save to pdf'.

Once I get them on the external hard drive, at least they'll be safe and I can do a few at a time.

One of my brothers died suddenly some months ago, and the emails both became more important and possibly more transitory -- like all of us. Something for all of us to think about -- texts too.

Thank you, David. I appreciate your amazingly fast help.

content: I was sad to read of your loss. It was my pleasure to assist. If there a lot of these messages, a quicker way might be to - highlight all of them and rightclick and 'save as' and point to a folder. each email will be saved individually - then, click to https://www.freeconvert.com/eml-to-pdf and upload all and the free software will convert each to pdf and with one click you can download them all.

Buongiorno

creator: n.gennari76

content:
Se il problema è quello descritto nel link, no. I file che contenevano la posta vengono azzerati per cui non c'è nulla da ripristinare.

Tuttavia non sono certo che sia il tuo caso: il problema si presente se sono vere tre condizioni: - Thunderbird a 32 bit - Account di tipo POP3 - Compattazione (o riparazione) di cartelle di grande dimensione (più di 4 GB)

Sei sicuro di rientrare in questa casistica?

Inoltre come hai letto nella discussioni, i messaggi non vengono cancellati dal server. Per cui se Thunderbird era impostato per lasciare copia dei messaggi sul server, dovreti avere ancora tutti i messaggi sul server. Hai verificato?

In alternativa l'unico modo di ripristinare i vecchi archivi è disporre di un backup (non hai risposto in merito).
